newsitem.title: USA: N.J. moves closer to adopting HMO safeguards.
newsitem.headline: N.J. moves closer to adopting HMO safeguards.

text.p: The New Jersey Senate voted Thursday to impose consumer safeguards on licensed health maintenance organizations.
"The 'Health Care Quality Act' will provide New Jerseyans with the strongest health care protections in the nation," said state Sen. Jack Sinagra, R-Monmouth, a co-sponsor.

It will guarantee that the two million people enrolled in HMOs can appeal coverage decisions to an independent panel and that primary care physicians not be limited in what they advise patients. It also prohibits financial incentives for limiting care.
HMOs must use a physician in any final decision to deny, reduce or terminate a medical procedure, under a key provision.
And finally, HMOs must register with the state Department of Health and follow its regulations.
The state has already adopted new rules dubbed the "HMO consumer's bill of rights," regarded as less stringent than the bill.
-- A choice of specialists, not just one presented by the HMO.
-- A guarantee that HMOs pay for emergency care, including ambulance transport and hospital screening, also that agreement on further emergency care cannot be rescinded.
-- A requirement that HMOs disclose any financial incentives to doctors in their network, and a prohibition on so-called "gag rules," limitations on what doctors can tell their patients.
-- An appeals process that culminates in a hearing before an independent review board, selected by the state.
-- Doctors be allowed to speak on all treatment options, including those not covered by the plan, and guaranteed that no retaliatory action could be taken.
